p: Tourism dominates not only the popular imagination about Venice but also its local politics. The city’s inhabitants have been experiencing the subordination of local social structures to tourist needs for decades, a process that has led to displacement through the establishment of a tourist monoculture. While the historic center had 174,808 inhabitants in 1951, the figure for 2014 was 56,311 (Casagrande 2016: 125). Although tourism has long been a lucrative business for investors and residents alike, it is mainly the latter who have addressed the industry’s negative effects on the city over the last two decades. These effects have driven the city’s inhabitants to the streets and squares in increasing numbers. Coalitions of associations, organizations, and committees are evidence not just of the city’s problems, but also of the initiative and agency of its inhabitants (cf. Araya López 2021; Dlabaja 2021). This engagement underlines Henri Lefebvre’s notion of the city “as a resource of society” (Schmid 2011: 32), and it shows a demand for participation in the shaping of the economic, social, and cultural resources which are increasingly being transferred to external stakeholders.
